subject: Transactionally update allocations (v1.13)
commit_message:
Transactionally update allocations (v1.13)

This patch does not adhere to the conventions of openstack CLI, because
the API exposed here is so complex I could not find a way to expose it
in the usual way. I went for the seemingly least bad of the following
alternatives:

* Do not list 1.13 as a supported microversion.
* List 1.13 as supported but then throw some explicit error when called.
* Provide some half-assed support. (this patch)

Please note that using 'resource provider allocation create' as usual
for POST requests would be misleading here because this POST method
explicitly supports "[c]reate, update or delete [operations] for
multiple consumers in a single request" as stated in the api-ref.
Instead this patch introduces 'resource provider allocation transact'.

The request body is also quite complex, it could be covered by
introducing command line arguments of the below complexity:

--allocation consumer_id=...,project_id=...,user_id=...,\
             rp=...|VCPU=2|MEMORY_MB=1024,rp=...|VCPU=2|MEMORY_MB=1024
[--allocation ...]

I find this not at all simpler than using JSON therefore we expect the
JSON formatted body because that is at least a well-known format.

forbidden traits in GET /resource_providers and GET

part of the required parameter with a "!" prefix:

Use notification listener pools

specifying pools for notification listeners is an approach alternative
to specifying multiple topics for notification emitters (and supscribing

subject: Make ACLs work with Unicode in user/account names
commit_message:
Make ACLs work with Unicode in user/account names

There were two separate complications:

  - Account ACLs are stored as JSON, so they were getting deserialized
    to Unicode. That's fine for ASCII names (as u'a' == b'a' under py2),
    but not arbitrary Unicode (as u'\u1234' != u'\u1234'.encode('utf8')
    for both py2 and py3). So, under py2, encode all account ACL members
    as UTF-8.

  - Container ACLs are stored as comma-separated values in a header, but
    values may contain arbitrary characters including not only non-ASCII
    Unicode but also commas and newlines. Fortunately, we have precedent
    for using URL-encoding in headers to resolve this. See crypto,
    symlink, dlo, versioned_writes, copy...

BIND stores dynamically created zones in /var/named by default,
which means that this directory needs to be persistent across
container restarts.  However, we can't just bind mount /var/named

the container the BIND package populates some necessary initial files
in it.

To address this, we can point BIND at /var/named-persistent and
copy all of the initial config from /var/named at container start,
just like we do for other configs.

subject: Use instance project/user when creating RequestSpec during resize reschedule
commit_message:
Use instance project/user when creating RequestSpec during resize reschedule

When rescheduling from a failed cold migrate / resize, the compute
service does not pass the request spec back to conductor so we
create one based on the in-scope variables.

This introduces a problem for some scheduler filters like the
AggregateMultiTenancyIsolation filter since it will create the
RequestSpec using the project and user information from the current
context, which for a cold migrate is the admin and might not be
the owner of the instance (which could be in some other project).
So the AggregateMultiTenancyIsolation filter might reject the
request or select a host that fits an aggregate for the admin but
not the end user.

This fixes the problem by using the instance project/user information
when constructing the RequestSpec which will take priority over
the context in RequestSpec.from_components().

Long-term we need the compute service to pass the request spec back
to the conductor during a reschedule, but we do this first since we
can backport it.

NOTE(mriedem): RequestSpec.user_id was added in Rocky in commit
6e49019fae80586c4bbb8a7281600cf6140c176a so we have to remove its
usage in this backport.

subject: Fix race condition with enabling SG on many ports at once
commit_message:
Fix race condition with enabling SG on many ports at once

When there are many calls to enable security groups on ports there
can be sometimes race condition between refresh recource_cache
with data get by "pull" call to neutron server and data received
with "push" rpc message from neutron server.
In such case when "push" message comes with information about
updated port (with enabled port_security), in local cache this port
is already updated so local AFTER_UPDATE call is not called for
such port and its rules in firewall are not updated.

It happend quite often in fullstack security groups test because
there are 4 ports created in this test and all 4 are updated to
apply SG to it one by one.
And here's what happen then in details:
1. port 1 was updated in neutron-server so it sends push notification
   to L2 agent to update security groups,
2. port 1 info was saved in resource cache on L2 agent's side and agent
   started to configure security groups for this port,
3. as one of steps L2 agent called
   SecurityGroupServerAPIShim._select_ips_for_remote_group() method;
   In that method RemoteResourceCache.get_resources() is called and this
   method asks neutron-server for details about ports from given
   security_group,
4. in the meantime neutron-server got port update call for second port
   (with same security group) so it sends to L2 agent informations about 2
   ports (as a reply to request sent from L2 agent in step 3),
5. resource cache updates informations about two ports in local cache,
   returns its data to
   SecurityGroupServerAPIShim._select_ips_for_remote_group() and all
   looks fine,
6. but now L2 agent receives push notification with info that port 2 is
   updated (changed security groups), so it checks info about this port
   in local cache,
7. in local cache info about port 2 is already WITH updated security
   group so RemoteResourceCache doesn't trigger local notification about
   port AFTER UPDATE and L2 agent doesn't know that security groups for this
   port should be changed

This patch fixes it by changing way how items are updated in
the resource_cache.
For now it is done with record_resource_update() method instead of
writing new values directly to resource_cache._type_cache dict.
Due to that if resource will be updated during "pull" call to neutron
server, local AFTER_UPDATE will still be triggered for such resource.

Change-Id: I5a62cc5731c5ba571506a3aa26303a1b0290d37b
Closes-Bug: #1742401
(cherry picked from commit 725df3e0382e048391fac109ea57920683eaf4d0)

that servers created with a zero disk flavor must also be

subject: Fix vmware disk type changed when volume type is eagerZeroedThick
commit_message:
Fix vmware disk type changed when volume type is eagerZeroedThick

Create a volume from an image, choose "eagerZeroedThick" volume_type.
But login in Vcenter, you will get a "lazyZeroedThick" volume. There
is no problem when creating a blank vmware volume.

The reason is: when creating a volume from image, if volueme_size
> image_size, the last step is to extend backing volume. In the method
extend_virtual_disk(), there is a parameter "eager_zero", which
determining if the free space is zeroed out. The param "eager_zero"
default value is "False", and not to be changed to "True" in creating
an eagerZeroedThick volume from an image. So the actuall volume type
is different with designated volume type.

We can add a paramter "disk_type" in _extend_backing() method,

By default number of MAC addresses which ovs stores in memory

Any eviction of a MAC learning table entry triggers revalidation.
Such revalidation is very costly so it cause high CPU usage by
ovs-vswitchd process.

To workaround this problem, higher value of mac-table-size
option can be set for bridge. Then this revalidation will happen
less often and CPU usage will be lower.
This patch adds config option for neutron-openvswitch-agent to allow
users tune this setting in bridges managed by agent.
By default this value is set to 50000 which should be enough for most
systems.

subject: Support aggregate affinity filters
commit_message:
Support aggregate affinity filters

Adds support for two new server group policies:

 * aggregate-affinity
 * aggregate-anti-affinity

Server groups that are tagged with the aggregate-affinity policy
indicate to the scheduler that instances should be placed on hosts that
share the same aggregate associations. The aggregate-anti-affinity
policy indicates that the scheduler should place instances on hosts that
are NOT associated with the same aggregates.

This functionality is useful for Ironic deployments where (with the
change to allow host aggregates to be associated with compute nodes and
not just service records) Ironic baremetal resource nodes are grouped
together in aggregates that represent racks or power failure domains.
The new aggregate affinity filters allow the caller of nova boot for
Ironic baremetal instances to pack or spread their instances in a
particular rack or power domain as needed.

subject: allow compute nodes to be associated with host agg
commit_message:
allow compute nodes to be associated with host agg

The Compute API allows for a host_name attribute to be specified
along with the aggregate's ID to associate or disassociate that host
with the aggregate. Unfortunately, due to vestigial coupling between the
compute service record and the compute node concept, this meant that
Ironic baremetal resource nodes cannot effectively use the Nova host
aggregate concept to group resource nodes. Instead, only the
nova-compute service(s) that manage those Ironic resource nodes can be
grouped together using a Nova host aggregate. This is less than useful
for Ironic deployments.

This patch does not change the public Compute API for adding or removing
hosts from an aggregate. Instead, what this patch does is fall back to
looking up compute node records by hypervisor_hostname if a service
record with the supplied hostname parameter cannot be found.

This work should pave the way for Ironic deployments to fully take
advantage of Nova server group affinity/anti-affinity and allow
HostAggregate metadata filters to operate on Ironic baremetal nodes in
the scheduler.

subject: Add live status report to object replicator
commit_message:
Add live status report to object replicator

The object replicator now has an internal scoreboard that contains
information about the currently-running replication jobs and also has
a socket interface for querying it.

The replicator's status report has things like partition, device,
storage policy, and peer to whom it is pushing for each active
replication job, plus the current stats for the replication pass and
the replicator's PID (to help with strace). It's easy to add more
things; anything JSON-serializable will work.

There's a new CLI tool called "swift-interrogate" that you can use to
query the running replicators. The output is pretty crude at the
moment, but it lets you see what your replicators are doing.

The socket interface uses Unix sockets in /var/run/swift, one per
replicator process, except for the master process in multi-process
mode as that process doesn't replicate anything.

The protocol is length-type-value; values are serialized JSON-RPC 2.0,
and the type is always 1. The type is there in case we outgrow
JSON-RPC.

There is no record for why we implement the database creation outside
of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the role.

which is used in the role to allow delegation of the database setup
task to any host, but defaults to the first member of the galera_all
host group. We also document the variable 'congress_galera_address' which
